role_mapping.DEFINITION_CORE: Core substances/simples (75% in A = definitional catalog)
role_mapping.EXPOSITION_CORE: Compound preparations/applications (88% in B = applied formulas)

operator_interpretation.POSITION: Entry structure markers (this preparation starts here)
operator_interpretation.SCOPE: Category shifters (from herb X to preparation type Y)

ab_function.A_text: Materia medica definitions - what each simple IS
ab_function.B_text: Pharmaceutical applications - how to USE combinations
ab_function.length_explanation: Applications require more detail (dosing, timing, preparation steps)

overlay.hub_interpretation: 8 major drug categories (purgatives, tonics, etc.) or humoral classes

tests.question: Does typical entry length (5-10 GAMMA tokens) make sense?
tests.reasoning: Materia medica entries typically list: substance, properties (2-3), preparations (2-3), applications (2-3). 5-10 core content elements is standard for herbal entries.

tests.question: Does A=short definitions, B=long expositions match domain workflow?
tests.model_facts: A=124 words, B=352 words (2.84x), DEFINITION_CORE 75% in A, EXPOSITION_CORE 88% in B
tests.reasoning: Materia medica DEFINES simples briefly in catalog form (A), then APPLIES them in compound preparations requiring detailed instructions (B). 2.84x length difference aligns with definition vs recipe elaboration.

tests.question: Do hub-shifting operators and positional markers make sense?
tests.model_facts: 6 POSITION, 16 SCOPE (>40% hub concentration), 8 SEMANTIC operators
tests.reasoning: Pharmacology needs: category markers (purgative, tonic), scope shifters (from herb to preparation type), and semantic modifiers (degree, part). Hub-shifting operators map to drug class changes within compounds.

tests.question: Do role cluster sizes match expected domain vocabulary structure?
tests.model_facts: DEFINITION=25 (75% A), EXPOSITION=33 (88% B), FLEXIBLE=35 (40% A), RESTRICTED=187 (26% A)
tests.reasoning: DEFINITION_CORE=25 base herbs. EXPOSITION_CORE=33 preparation types. FLEXIBLE_CORE=35 common modifiers (hot, cold, degrees). RESTRICTED_CORE=187 specific properties/effects. Distribution matches materia medica vocabulary structure.

tests.question: Why would domain X abstract away referents (no named plants, etc.)?
tests.reasoning: Pharmacological shorthand is historically common. Practitioners used category codes, not full plant names. Secrecy, space constraints, and professional jargon all justify abstraction. Apothecaries' marks were intentionally opaque.

tests.question: Could 8 major categories naturally organize domain X?
tests.model_facts: 8 hubs, mean heading length 4.0 chars, functional roles (opener/closer/support)
tests.reasoning: 8 drug categories is plausible: purgatives, emetics, tonics, sedatives, febrifuges, digestives, topicals, compound preparations. Medieval pharmacology often used ~8 major groupings.

tests.reasoning: Alchemy is FAMOUS for deliberate obscurity. Decknamen (cover names), symbolic encoding, and intentional veiling of processes is the historical norm. Abstraction is expected, even required.

tests.question: Do role cluster sizes match expected domain vocabulary structure?

tests.question: Why would domain X abstract away referents (no named plants, etc.)?
